instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message:
Hello Everybody

I'm working on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, first problem was <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> create problem. it solved after <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> ,<RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> changed but now <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> voltage is too low (1.5V) . <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> line to <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> resistance is 30ohm but it must 8.5-9K around ( i checked with known good board)

Also changed <RESISTOR>R5070</RESISTOR> and removed <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> nothing changed, only when removed SMC resistance is ok ..

Replaced 5th SMC but same resistance and 1.5V is same :(  soo no green light or no power.

Where can i check next step ...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message: What is resistance to GND now, are you measuring this without power and keyboard connected?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message: 30ohm is resistance at ground. (disconnected power and keyboard )

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> or corrosion in KB connector?
Also <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> must be present, board will not work without.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message:
Thanks Duke suggestion

Removed <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> but same resistance:( Double time checked keyboard connector but looking good...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message: What SMC are you using to replace it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message: Duke replaced from same code donor boards SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> low voltage
threads.message:
30 ohm makes no sense. I see in your other thread you are measuring ohms with battery plugged in, you can't do that!
It makes no sense that multiple SMC give the same problem. It can only be shit around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> as there is nothing else connected besides SMC, <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR>.
